Function Documentation

public status mat_assign (  matrix    dest,
matrix    orig
) 
 

MAT dest = orig.

Transfer ([m] x [n]) elements from 2 to 1.

Assigns the values of one matrix to another. Both matrices must have the same dimensions, otherwise an error result will occur.

If the origin matrix is NULL, then the destination matrix will be set to the null matrix (i.e. all of its elements initialized to zero).

Parameters:
dest  the destination matrix
orig  the origin matrix
Returns:
SUCCESS if all went well, an error code otherwise

public status mat_invert (  matrix    B,
matrix    C
) 
 

MAT B = INV ( C );.

Computes the inverted matrix of C, which is a square matrix n x n and stores the result on B. The algorithm employed is a modification of Gauss' method. This is probably not the best (nor is it the nicest implementation), but for the moment will do.

Given the identity matrix Inn, we may think of another such that

A B = B A = I => B = A-1

A A-1 = I = A-1 A

Using the cofactors of Aij we may compute

A-1 = 1 / |A| · adj(A)

(calculating through the adjunct matrix). If |A| = 0 then it is not defined and A is SINGULAR.

The inverse of a matrix A, if it exists, is unique and may be found: We first form for Ann the matrix An x 2n

That is, the left half is A and the right half I, the identity matrix. Using a modified Gauss method we transform the former matrix into

Now the left half is I and the right half, B is the inverse of A.

To avoid changing matrix C we get first a working copy that we store in matrix A, whose space is reserved ex-profeso and is freed upon termination.

public status mat_transpose (  matrix    trn,
matrix    mat
) 
 

MAT trn = TRN(mat) Compute the transpose of a matrix.

The transpose AT of a matrix A is A' = AT / row A' = col A =>

(A)ij = (AT)ji

Thus, if Am·n, then A'n.m =>

If A · B = C -> C' = A' · B'

We may therefore describe a column vector as a row vector

Parameters:
trn  a matrix where we will store the transpose
mat  the matrix whose transpose we want to take
